Award.AwardTitle: Conference on the Foundations of Computational Mathematics 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports increased participation of US researchers at the Conference on the Foundations of Computational Mathematics (FoCM), hosted by the Universidad de la Republica in Montevideo, between December 11 - 20, 2014. The conference, organized by the Society for the Foundations of Computational Mathematics, is eighth in a sequence that commenced with the Park City (1995), Rio de Janeiro (1997), Oxford (1999), Minneapolis (2002), Santander (2005), Hong Kong (2008), and Budapest (2011) FoCM meetings. The NSF funding predominantly supports participation of qualified US-based graduate students, postdocs, and recent Ph.D. recipients in the conference, either as workshop speakers or as poster presenters, promoting their integration into the research community. The conference's diverse activities -- distinguished plenary talks, specialized workshops, poster session, and informal interactions between participants -- all integrate front-line research with mentoring and training opportunities for young participants, helping them develop networks that include the world's leading researchers. Central to the overall conference organization is the organizer's continuing commitment to the tradition that FoCM conferences welcome and integrate newcomers into the research community.

The FoCM conference offers an effective forum for the dissemination of research results across diverse fields within computational mathematics, capitalizing on a rapid evolution in our understanding of the interplay between mathematics and computation. The organizers and committed participants of the conference have a history of intellectual and service contributions to the foundations of computational mathematics. The conference program includes 17 plenary speakers who are among the leading researchers in the field; the organizers of the 19 workshops are chosen to include both established senior and talented junior researchers, their potential, diversity and creativity promising a vibrant scientific program. Many of the confirmed plenary speakers and workshop organizers at FoCM are from the US, reflecting the vitality of US based research in a variety of disciplines within computational mathematics. The award will advance the international exposure of research conducted in the US, and will have long-term effects in catalyzing new collaborations between US and international participants of the conference.

Conference web site: www.fing.edu.uy/eventos/focm2014/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supplied funds to partially support 17 partipants from the US to attend the 2014 Conference on the Foundations of Computational Mathematics (FoCM'14) in Montevideo, Uruguay, between December 11 - 20, 2014. Eleven of the seventeen supported participants were junior researchers working in the US: graduate students, postdocs or recently hired tenure track assistant professors. All of the junior participants that were funded gave talks or poster presentations. The supported senior participants were plenary speakers and/or workshop organizers from the US, advancing the international exposure of research conducted in the US and fostering multidisciplinary interaction across subjects and disciplines.

The FoCM'14 Conference lasted 9 days. There were 20 workshops, 18 plenary talks, and around 400 presentations. I have attached the detailed program of the conference and one can see the wide breadth of areas represented. For more information concerning the conference see https://www.fing.edu.uy/eventos/focm2014/.

Central to the conference organization was the mentoring and training of junior faculty, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students, helping them develop networks that include the world's leading researchers. We encouraged workshop organizers to include talented students and junior researchers in the program as invited speakers. Senior members of the Society of the Foundations of Computational Mathematics looked out for junior researchers in an informal way, involving them in the social activities - e.g. lunches and dinners - during the conference. 

The feedback from all participants confirmed that there was a lot of interaction between junior and senior participants leading to further integration of the junior researchers into the research community. In addition, several of the junior researchers noted that presenting their work lead to interesting feedback and made them comfortable with seeking out contact with the senior as well as other junior researchers in the future.

The tradition of broadening the diversity of participation is also continued at the FoCM'14 conference. The committees appointing the workshop organizers and the plenary speakers for FoCM'14 strived for strong representation by traditionally under-represented groups. Throughout the scientific organization of the conference, workshop organizers are directed to broaden the pool of participants, including participation by women, minorities, persons with disabilities, and other traditionally under-represented groups.
